title: So are we going to see an ap assassin item?
body: I mean considering how many assassin items have come out, WHICH ARE BEING NERFED BECAUSE BROKEN *ahem* we should also see a release of a new assassin item, for ability based champions ({{champion:84}} {{champion:55}} {{champion:28}} {{champion:60}} {{champion:7}} {{champion:76}} )Are all unable to use any of the new ad assassin items, at least not well or even cost efficiently. But no no, creating an ad assassin item that is a better banshees is fine, really np. No.. favoritism or anything :^) It's glaringly obvious that the ad champions needed something new, but seriously, theres hardly an item that's specifically FOR ap assassins, yet how many are for ad assassins?

What about utilising close range passives/actives to prevent abuse from the majority of burst mages. Or even, items that reduce the effectiveness of stats that mages generally build.

e.g.

Tormented Rod - 2850g
+85 AP
+10 Magic Penetration
+5% Movement Speed
[Unique: Active - Perpetual Torment:] Marks a target for 2 seconds (300 range), after the 2 seconds are over, the mark pops, dealing an additional 20% AP damage dealt by the user to the opponent while marked.

Phantasmic Cloak - 2700g
+70 AP
+25 Magic Penetration
-10% Cooldown Reduction
[Unique: Passive - Dance of Demise:] For every champion kill, gain 40% movement speed decaying over 3 seconds.

I think the general idea is good - to incentive the item(s) for assassins while discouraging mages from making the items core.  However, the examples you created probably aren't there yet.

The "Tormented Rod" is a LOT of AP for its cost (considering how few >80 AP items there are currently), and mages would be likely to pick it up just for that even with the short range on the active. Battle mages or close combat mages in general would certainly take it (Ryze, Lissandra, etc), and it isn't too hard to believe that it could become a standard anti-assassin mage item (You're going to jump on me? Here, let me just mark you, unload my burst, then Zhonya's/Flash and laugh when the mark kills you.)

For the "negative stats" idea, I like it when looking at items like Sterak's Gage (Marksmen abusing it? -20% crit from items) since it's easy to distinguish between the intended class's desired stats and the abusing class's. With AP assassins and mages, it's a bit harder - both like AP, mana, and cdr. I don't know if you could really take any of those away without making the item equally unappealing for the assassins. 

As far as item passives/actives that encourage assassins but discourage mages, what about a persistent effect while you are close (200-300 units) to an enemy champion - increased movespeed or cdr, for example - it could be the AP version of Black Cleaver's "Rage" passive: dealing magic damage to a champion within 200 units gives you 20 movement speed for 2 seconds; kills/assists on a champion give 60 movespeed, regardless of distance. A few non-assassins might be able to take advantage of it (mostly hybrid champions like Jax and Warwick, if they went for an AP build), but very few mages would want that effect very much.

Or, while you are within 200 units of an enemy champion, your abilities cool down twice as fast (possibly with an internal cooldown - approaching an enemy triggers this effect, lasting for up to 5 seconds with a 15 second cooldown). Killing an enemy while the effect is active grants the effect for an additional 5 seconds, regardless of enemy proximity.

I feel like those kinds of effects (utility, rather than straight damage) would be very attractive to assassins while being unappealing to mages either because of the effects themselves or the proximity requirement. They would help assassins stick to their targets more easily and also get out if they score a kill (increased movespeed to run, or cooldowns halved so they can get their escape back up quickly).

The problem is that all AP champions scale with one (and a secondary) stat: AP and CDR. 

Whereas your AD champions have different scaling based on their role:
AD assassins scale with AD and armor pen because their abilities do physical damage but they don't basic attack much.
AD juggernauts/bruisers often scale with base or total AD and HP, because they're meant to build a damage item or two and they like Sheen procs but they still need to be beefy to function.
ADCs scale with AD and crit, since most of their damage comes from attacks and they have attack steroids.

That's a lot of levers you can tune to address the specific class you need to address. Unless you added some new dimension, there's not much diversity that's even possible with AP champions, because even the AP assassins often don't rely much on basic attacks (with a couple exceptions). All you can really do is tweak base damages, AP scaling, and CC duration.

Magic Pen.

Still not as many as AD, but it is a third (more if you consider percent and flat separately).
Well right, but they've seemingly moved away from that. Old Vel'Koz and old Zyra were pretty strong with Mpen builds, but now they're built like everyone else.
And yet I see Sorcery Boots and Void Staff almost every game.  It's still a common stat for mages.

Both of those are cases of "the other items just aren't as good." It's the same with Marks (red runes) actually. I mean, what else are you going to get as a mage? MPen is the only "Primary" red rune that's any good for mages, while ADs can choose between AD, Lethality, and AS (or even Crit if you wanted!)

Similarly, Sorcerer's boots are the only good offensive option for a lot of mages, since additional CDR typically isn't necessary once you're already at or near the cap from some combination of {{item:3001}} {{item:3152}} {{item:3100}} {{item:3165}} {{item:3157}} and runes.

And Void Staff is just incredibly strong against everyone, since it's 35% total Magic Penetration. It works just as well against tanks as squishies.

Don't get me wrong, I'm glad those items are all in the game, as it does add some diversity, but Riot hasn't shown any interest in increasing the availability of MPen in game or supporting weird low-AP high-pen builds.

They just need to make more AP items with unique passives and actives to actually differentiate them.  Right now there really doesn't seem to be anything unique they can do with just stats for AP itemization without being either useless or op.

Hard to make AP assassin items because there's no distinction between an AP assassin and a burst mage. AD assassins VS Marksmen is an entirely different matter.
